BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 27, 1920.

METHODISTS MEET A TARTAR

SECOND PRESENTATION SUCCESS

CONCERT AND DANCE ON FRIDAY

Black and Blue Nine Too Good For
Western Maryland—Owings Pitches
Fine Game—Sharretts Starts in
Field and With the Bat.

Audience Small But Enthusiastic—Leber and Burger Star.

Annual McCoy Hall Concert To Be
Held at Homewood — Formal
Dance to Follow.

After losing the last three
games played, the Johns Hopkins
balltossers finally found themselves and trimmed Western
Maryland College to the tune of
5 to 2. The 'Varsity showed a
decided improvement over their
past performances, for the team
combined hitting, pitching and
fielding, instead of shining in one
department and falling down in
the others.
"Bobby" Owings was the star
of the game, for, in addition to
holding the visitors to five scattered hits and striking out as
many men, he hit safely and
scored what proved to be the
winning run in the fifth. He
was seldom in trouble, and was
backed up by snappy fielding at
all critical times. After Norment had doubled in the fifth and
Hutton had gotten on through an
error, a pretty double play (Sharretts to Egerton) cut off all
chances of a rally. "Shad" Shan
retts contributed the fielding
feature of the day by a beautiful
catch of Long's low smash, just
a moment before he started the
twin killing. Knecht, Egerton
and Sharretts, for the'home team,
and Norment and Clayton, for the
visitors, were the batting stars.
. Owings, aided by snappy fielding, retired the Methodists in onetwo-three order in the first two
innings. He worked easily, anA
had no difficulty in locating the
plate. In the third, he was
touched for a single, but later the
runner failed to touch second and
was doubled up after a fly to
centerfield. In the fourth inning,
he came back strong and struck
out the first two men who faced
him.
Clayton, who faced Hopkins
last season, also started off well
and was in no danger during the
.first three innings. In the fourth,
however, the fireworks started.
After Littman had been disposed
of, Egerton singled to left center.
Sharretts lived up to his reputation of being the "Ty" Cobb of
the local nine and drove a smashing triple over the centerfielder's
head, and Egerton crossed the
plate. "Shad" also scored a moment later on "Andy" Knecht's
drive to right.
In the following frame, Western Maryland threatened, but
Sharrett's beautiful p la ying
nipped the rally before it was
well under way. The 'Varsity,
however, were not so easy, for

PRICE, FIVE CENTS
LACROSSE TEAM VICTORIOUS •
Defeats Harvard In One of Hardest
Games Ever Played on the Homewood Field — Two Extra
Periods Required.

,1 ohns Hopkins defeated the lacrosse team of Harvard University last Satnrday, 2 to 1, in one
of the hardest fought games ever
seen on Homewood Field. After
a week of stiff contests, which included defeats at the hands of
Navy and Mt. 'Washington, the
Crimson players forced the Black
and Blue through two extra periods of ten minutes each before
the tie was broken. Both squads
put all they had into the battle,
and the play was often very
rough.
The first half was scoreless;
.Hopkins was shooting from far
out, and the Crimson attack
could make no headway against
their opponents' defense. Only
once did they have a real chance,
when Hall, the Harvard in-home,
missed an easy chance a few feet
from the crease. There was nothing to stop the ball, but it wentwide, and the period ended scoreless. •
Early in the second half the
ball came down the field, and
Stuart"shoveled" it in for the first
score. Harvard came back and
tied the count when Thompson.
registered. From then on the
ball see-sawed back and forth.
The Harvard players were following their men closely, • and
passing was difficult.
With the spectators shouting,
"Play it out!" it was decided to
continue for an extra period; this
was done, but the score remained
tied at 1-all. A second .period
was half gone when Defandorf
shot the winning goal. Harvard
tried hard to tie the count again,
but . failed.
A great deal of credit is due
Pratt, the Crimson goalkeeper.
Although knocked out once and
again struck on the head with the
ball, he remained in the game
and was chiefly resposible forholding Hopkins' score down.

Swarthmore defeated the Hopkins track and field team Saturday by a score of 58. to 54 in a
hotly contested meet. The issue
was in doubt from start to finish,
first Hopkins and then Swarthmore forging ahead, and at the
end the decision hinged on the
'result of the 220-yard dash. In
this event, the Hopkins supporters were cheered by seeing Van
Ness jump into what seemed a
commanding lead at the start,
but their hopes crumbled when
within 20 yards of the tape the
Black and Blue runner faltered,
and Spackman, of Swarthmore,
squeezed in a winner. This gave
Swarthmore 58 points to Hopkins' 54.
A number of thincrs seemed to
conspire to prevent the
6 Homewood
boys from garnering the laurels:
Had three men run and 'third
places counted, had the "blacklist" been decorated with the
names of fewer track stars, had
the field men shown up but a little stronger, the outcome would
Probably have been more satisfying to Hopkins' rooters.
The work of Thompson in winning the 440 and the 220 hurdles
and placing second in the 100
was an outstanding feature. All
three of these races were run in
fine time, and his performance
in each was up to that expected
of him. Edwards, in winning the
half-mile event in easy fashion,
also won himself an assured position on the team. Captain Bartels won first in the mile and
second in the half in such easy
fashion that one wondered what
he would have done if pushed.
In the two-mile, Swarthmore
never had a chance, Norwood and
Grave leading the whole way.
Either could' have won, but
Grave pulled away when "Bill"
felt himself weakening from a
fall he sustained at the end of the
fourth lap. The strong wind hindered the runners, so that the
time, while good, does not begin
to express their speed and endurance.
It was in the field events that
Swarthmore outclassed the Black
and Blue.
In these events,
Swarthmore captured every first
and most of the seconds.

Dr. J. E. Gilpin, professor of
chemistry, has just had an all-day
conference of the architect of the
Homewood buildings in hope of
completing plans for a new chemiistry building. It is hoped that
the trustees will arrange to start
the building in the fall. It will be
two years before it can be occupied.

There will be, on April 30, the
annual concert of the Johns Hopkins Musical Clubs at Homewood.
Will we, the student body of
Johns Hopkins University, treat
these organizations with the same
disgraceful apathy that was accorded the Dramatic Club? If

can be but one inference drawn
therefrom. Let us hope that this
verdict be not forced upon us!
THE NEWS-LETTER wishes to
apologize once more for lateness
in appearing. This time it is. due
to the kidnapping of the Managing Editor, with a large proportion of the copy for the issue, by
members of the Freshman Class.
As only part of. the copy was recovered, THE NEWS-LETTER begs
the indulgence of any organization, a record of whose activities
may have been omitted this week,
since it was impossible to determine absolutely whether everything had received proper attention.

THE NEWS-LETTER prints with
pl,easure the following letters received by Dr. Goodnow :
April 20, 1920.
DR. F. J. GOODNOW,
President, Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, Md.
MY DEAR-SIR:
I desire to express to you, as the
head of the Johns Hopkins University, the high appreciation of
the management of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company of the
assistance given by the students
of the University in carrying on
our operations during the recent
strike.
A sufficient number,of students
reported to us to fill our requirements, and they showed a spirit
and disposition in their willingness to serve us worthy of the
highest commendation, and the
men who were used to perform
various tasks, all of which were
unfamiliar to them and most of
which were diriy and laborious,
took hold with a spirit of determination and showed an intelligence
in doing the work which provoked
the warm admiration of the company's officers who had charge of
them.
We wish to thank you heartily
and sincerely for permitting these
young men to come to our assistance, and hope that you will express to the students who were
accepted for the service, as well
as those who offered and could not
be accepted, our high appreciation
of their willingness to assist us.
Yours respectfully,
G. R. SINNICKSON,
Superintendent.
Dn. F. J. GIOODNOW,
President, Johns Hopkins Uiviversity, Baltimore, Md.
DEAR DR. GOODNOW :
Now that the critical transportation situation, caused by many
of our employees leaving their positions, has in a large measure
passed, I want to express, on behalf of,the officers of the Pennsylvania System, thanks and appreciation for the assistance rendered us in the emergency by the
students of your institution.
We are deeply grateful for your
co-operation in making it possible
for your undergraduates to temporarily leave their studies, and
to the boys who, from a sense of
public duty, so whole-heartedly
threw themselves into the breach
and enabled us to cope with the

There has been established at
this University within the past
few weeks a company of "The
Scabbard and Blade," an honorary fraternity for the members of
the Reserve Officers' Training
Corps. Its chief mission is to
instil such a spirit into the work
of the Military Department that
the latter will be enabled to graduate, after four years of intensive
training, reserve officers of the
highest possible type.
The society is an old one, and
has its companies in a great number of the foremost military institutions throughout the country.
Johns Hopkins is one of the first
of those institutions which are
not purely military, to be added
to its roll of companies. Membership is limited to such. of the
cadet commissioned officers who
have reached a prescribed standard of proficiency, and as such is
.a great& coveted honor.
Steps were taken early this
spring toward securing the formation of a company at Johns
*Hopkins, and affairs moved in
such a manner that the installation of the charter members was
held on Thursday, April 8. This
initiation ceremony took place at
the Hotel Emerson, and was preceded by a dinner. The charter
members include Cadet Captains
Fred Bresee, Jr., L. G. Smith and
H. B. Shaw, and Lieutenants F.
H. Townsend, C. I. Krantz, F. F.
Torsch and N. N. Holland. Captain 0. 0. Ellis is the first honorary member.
At the first business meeting,
on Thursday of last week, at the
Johns Hopkins Club, the formal
organization was completed. Fred
Bresee was elected captain of the
company, F. H. Townsend its
first lieutenant, C. I. Krantz its
second lieutenant, and L. G.
Smith its first sergeant. The chief
topic of discussion was the work
which is still necessary to be done
if• this R. 0. T. C. unit is to be
placed upon the distinguished
list.
In order to further promote
discussion of the honor system
among the undergraduates of
Dartmouth College, The Bailsmonth (the college daily paper)
has arranged a monster debate on
this. subject. Two of the best debaters of the college have agreed
to take the affirmative against all
comers. '

the students there are said to
show a surprising lack of humor.

To the Editor of THE NEws-LETTER:

Junior Class Meeting.

At a recent meeting of the
Junior Class, Prof. C. C. Thomas,
of the School of Engineering, was
elected honorary president. A
banquet committee, consisting of
Bond Collins, chairman; Holmes
Boyd and E. R. Taylor, was also
elected.

According to recent statistics,
795 Princeton men are engaged
in campus activities. This includes men out for athletics, musical clubs and college publication. Nearly one-half of the
places in the sports are filled by
freshmen, while the majority of
men in other activities are in the
higher classes.

The National Football Rules'
Committee has decided that football shall be played without the
punt out after the touchdown.
The team making the touchdown
can bring the football out to any
distance and to a point directly
in front of the goal posts or elsewhere, and the try for the goal
will remain a free kick .from
placement.
•

Sir—The other day one of our
illustrious representatives to the
Student Council, when that illustrious body was discussing the
question of awards to non-athletic
activities in the University, somewhat startled the president of
the oldest activity at Hopkins by
proposing that it receive no recognition. When the young man
under discussion made the statement that the "Combined Musical
Clubs of the Johns Hopkins University" is dead, he displayed one
of two things: Either that he does
not appreciate good music, both
classical or modern, for which he
is to be pitied; or that, as he
does not support the Hopkins ac' tivities, he is not truly a representative of the student body, for
which he should be compelled to
mete out this latter just reward.
I suggest that the young man
prevent displaying such startling
ignorance again by purchasing a
ticket to .the Homewood concert,
to be given on April 30.
A. G.L.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, APRIL
INTER-CLASS MEET SUCCESS

RADIO APPARATUS INSTALLED

Spirited Competition Shown and Much
New Material Revealed—Freshmen Easily Winners.

Several Successful Experiments Have
Been Made—improvements to Be
Made in Near Future.

The freshmen were easily victorious in the inter-class track
meet, held on Homewood Field
last Monday, amassing a total of
79 points, more than twice as
many as the sophomores, who
came second with 321/
2. The juniors and seniors annexed 201/
2 and
16 points, respectively. Nevertheless, the meet was spirited and
brought forth much latent "pep"
and material in the four classes.
Aaronson, a freshman, sprang
a big surprise by romping off
with four first places, besides running on the winning relay team.
He was the highest individual
point-winner, with "Joe" Thompson, captain of the freshman
team, second, and John Marshall,
the sophomore "dark horse,"
third. Heiner, a junior, captured
the 440-yard junior, while Edwards, a freshman, won the 880yard junior. Mu'liken, running
true to form, walked away with
the 1,000-yard senior 'Varsity,
with Norwood, a senior, and
Graves, a graduate, second and
third, respectively. The half-mile
relay was the most hotly contested event of the day, and was won
by the freshmen'in 1 minute 383/s
seconds over the sophomore team.
Summary of events:

Very gratifying results have
been accomplished by a few of
the radio enthusiasts at Hopkins.
Through the efforts of Dr. E. 0.
Hulburt, a license has been procured, and the apparatus installed
in the Mechanical Engineering
Building is now being operated.
The transmitter consists of a onehalf, 500 cycle panel set, manufactured by the National Electric
Signaling Company. For receiving purposes, various - types of
vacuum tubes and amplifiers are
employed.
Several nights ago, J. C. Lewis,
B. Van Ness and W. U. Evans
succeeded in communicating with
an amateur station located at
Cambridge Springs, Pa., a distance of about 300 miles. Loud
signals have been reported by several Washington stations, and the
first of a series of tests with the
Bureau of Standards located
there has been successfully carHed out. Further tests are being arranged by Mr. Gregory
Breit, a graduate student in'radio
engineering. Another advance
will be the construction and installation of a radio-phone set.
Some inefficiency is due to the
very large antennae, which is
about twice as long as it should
be for work on the lower range
of wave lengths to which amateur
and experimental stations are restricted. However, Dr. Hulburt
has arranged to have another antennae constructed, and this
should increase the efficiency to
such an extent that it will be
reasonable to hope to communicate with stations within a radius
of a thousand miles.
The experiments have been carried on under the direction of Dr.
E. 0. Hulburt, who had much
experience in radio while in
France, and is now conducting
the radio course at Hopkins.

In a recent number of the Synthese Historique," which was dedicated to the United States, appeared a very able article entitled, "L'esprit national dans la
poesie Americaine" (The distinctive American spirit evident in
American poetry), by Dr. Chinard, of the French faculty. Dr.
Chinard says that America has
produced as many as a hundred
distinctly American poets—poets
who are not English poets writing in America, but American
poets writing in a style which
the American nation alone can
produce, and with a philosophy
distinctly American.
Dr. Chinard's preference among
American poets seems to be Whittier. He says that although
Whittier is not as polished as
either Emerson, with his philosophical studies, or Longfellow,
with his wealth of books, he is,
nevertheless—if any poet can be
said to represent the entire American nation, with its diverse divisions and consequently differences of occupation and temperament—the true American poet of
the middle of the nineteenth century.
The latest truly American poet
is Walt Whitman, who, says Dr.
Chinard, could have been produced in no other place than
America. He seems, however,
somewhat afraid of the radical
and fervent democracy of Whitman, and hastens to caution his
readers against the radicalism of
this great distinctively American
poet.

week.

FULTON BRAMBLE GIVES TALK
"Joseph Conrad" Was the Subject Read
Before the Literary Club Last Friday—Max Levin Gives Reading.

"Joseph Conrad" was the subject of a carefully prepared paper read before the Literary Club
by Fulton Bramble last Friday
evening at the Homewood Club.
Max Levin also presented the first
half of his discourse on "Jews
and Their Literature" at this
meting.
Bramble first gave a brief biography of Joseph Conrad, and
then proceeded to point out the
distinctive characteristics of his
novels. In this connection, he
read a number of passages from
Conrad's representative works to
illustrate the author's unique
power.

Conrad was a native of Poland,
and his mastery of English, a foreign language, is consequently all
the greater achievement. His
first novels, indeed, bear evidence
of this early struggle with a new
language, acquired only after
years of residence in Poland.
The characters of Conrad's
novels are singularly natural persons, and each novel merely gives
a series of episodes from their
lives. He rarely analyses their
characters, but prefers to leave
the reader to form his own impressions. The absence of a
strong plot is the principal weakness of Conrad's novels, and for
this reason it is probable that
they will not long enjoy great
popularity, was Bramble's conclusion.

paper, Max Levin read the first
half of his paper on "Jews and

Their Literature." The discourse
was, as he explained, really only
an introduction to the second
half of his paper. Levin traced •
the history of the Jewish people
from the time of Abraham up to
the death of Christ, and dwelt
particularly upon the, contributions of the Hebrew writers to
the Old Testament. The books of
the Prophets, Levin pointed out,
contain some of the sublimest
poetry in any literature.
At the next meeting, May 7,
Levin will read the remainder of
his paper, and W. Wiscott will
present a paper on "Andreyeff
and Russian Literature." President Goetz announced that an
effort was being made to secure
Alfred Noyes and Vachel Lindsay
to speak before the club.

BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 27, 1920.

METHODISTS MEET A TARTAR

SECOND PRESENTATION SUCCESS

CONCERT AND DANCE ON FRIDAY

Black and Blue Nine Too Good For
Western Maryland—Owings Pitches
Fine Game—Sharretts Starts in
Field and With the Bat.

Audience Small But Enthusiastic—Leber and Burger Star.

Annual McCoy Hall Concert To Be
Held at Homewood — Formal
Dance to Follow.

After losing the last three
games played, the Johns Hopkins
balltossers finally found themselves and trimmed Western
Maryland College to the tune of
5 to 2. The 'Varsity showed a
decided improvement over their
past performances, for the team
combined hitting, pitching and
fielding, instead of shining in one
department and falling down in
the others.
"Bobby" Owings was the star
of the game, for, in addition to
holding the visitors to five scattered hits and striking out as
many men, he hit safely and
scored what proved to be the
winning run in the fifth. He
was seldom in trouble, and was
backed up by snappy fielding at
all critical times. After Norment had doubled in the fifth and
Hutton had gotten on through an
error, a pretty double play (Sharretts to Egerton) cut off all
chances of a rally. "Shad" Shan
retts contributed the fielding
feature of the day by a beautiful
catch of Long's low smash, just
a moment before he started the
twin killing. Knecht, Egerton
and Sharretts, for the'home team,
and Norment and Clayton, for the
visitors, were the batting stars.
. Owings, aided by snappy fielding, retired the Methodists in onetwo-three order in the first two
innings. He worked easily, anA
had no difficulty in locating the
plate. In the third, he was
touched for a single, but later the
runner failed to touch second and
was doubled up after a fly to
centerfield. In the fourth inning,
he came back strong and struck
out the first two men who faced
him.
Clayton, who faced Hopkins
last season, also started off well
and was in no danger during the
.first three innings. In the fourth,
however, the fireworks started.
After Littman had been disposed
of, Egerton singled to left center.
Sharretts lived up to his reputation of being the "Ty" Cobb of
the local nine and drove a smashing triple over the centerfielder's
head, and Egerton crossed the
plate. "Shad" also scored a moment later on "Andy" Knecht's
drive to right.
In the following frame, Western Maryland threatened, but
Sharrett's beautiful p la ying
nipped the rally before it was
well under way. The 'Varsity,
however, were not so easy, for

LACROSSE TEAM VICTORIOUS •
Defeats Harvard In One of Hardest
Games Ever Played on the Homewood Field — Two Extra
Periods Required.

,1 ohns Hopkins defeated the lacrosse team of Harvard University last Satnrday, 2 to 1, in one
of the hardest fought games ever
seen on Homewood Field. After
a week of stiff contests, which included defeats at the hands of
Navy and Mt. 'Washington, the
Crimson players forced the Black
and Blue through two extra periods of ten minutes each before
the tie was broken. Both squads
put all they had into the battle,
and the play was often very
rough.
The first half was scoreless;
.Hopkins was shooting from far
out, and the Crimson attack
could make no headway against
their opponents' defense. Only
once did they have a real chance,
when Hall, the Harvard in-home,
missed an easy chance a few feet
from the crease. There was nothing to stop the ball, but it wentwide, and the period ended scoreless. •
Early in the second half the
ball came down the field, and
Stuart"shoveled" it in for the first
score. Harvard came back and
tied the count when Thompson.
registered. From then on the
ball see-sawed back and forth.
The Harvard players were following their men closely, • and
passing was difficult.
With the spectators shouting,
"Play it out!" it was decided to
continue for an extra period; this
was done, but the score remained
tied at 1-all. A second .period
was half gone when Defandorf
shot the winning goal. Harvard
tried hard to tie the count again,
but . failed.
A great deal of credit is due
Pratt, the Crimson goalkeeper.
Although knocked out once and
again struck on the head with the
ball, he remained in the game
and was chiefly resposible forholding Hopkins' score down.

Swarthmore defeated the Hopkins track and field team Saturday by a score of 58. to 54 in a
hotly contested meet. The issue
was in doubt from start to finish,
first Hopkins and then Swarthmore forging ahead, and at the
end the decision hinged on the
'result of the 220-yard dash. In
this event, the Hopkins supporters were cheered by seeing Van
Ness jump into what seemed a
commanding lead at the start,
but their hopes crumbled when
within 20 yards of the tape the
Black and Blue runner faltered,
and Spackman, of Swarthmore,
squeezed in a winner. This gave
Swarthmore 58 points to Hopkins' 54.
A number of thincrs seemed to
conspire to prevent the
6 Homewood
boys from garnering the laurels:
Had three men run and 'third
places counted, had the "blacklist" been decorated with the
names of fewer track stars, had
the field men shown up but a little stronger, the outcome would
Probably have been more satisfying to Hopkins' rooters.
The work of Thompson in winning the 440 and the 220 hurdles
and placing second in the 100
was an outstanding feature. All
three of these races were run in
fine time, and his performance
in each was up to that expected
of him. Edwards, in winning the
half-mile event in easy fashion,
also won himself an assured position on the team. Captain Bartels won first in the mile and
second in the half in such easy
fashion that one wondered what
he would have done if pushed.
In the two-mile, Swarthmore
never had a chance, Norwood and
Grave leading the whole way.
Either could' have won, but
Grave pulled away when "Bill"
felt himself weakening from a
fall he sustained at the end of the
fourth lap. The strong wind hindered the runners, so that the
time, while good, does not begin
to express their speed and endurance.
It was in the field events that
Swarthmore outclassed the Black
and Blue.
In these events,
Swarthmore captured every first
and most of the seconds.

THE NEWS-LETTER prints with
pl,easure the following letters received by Dr. Goodnow :
April 20, 1920.
DR. F. J. GOODNOW,
President, Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, Md.
MY DEAR-SIR:
I desire to express to you, as the
head of the Johns Hopkins University, the high appreciation of
the management of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company of the
assistance given by the students
of the University in carrying on
our operations during the recent
strike.
A sufficient number,of students
reported to us to fill our requirements, and they showed a spirit
and disposition in their willingness to serve us worthy of the
highest commendation, and the
men who were used to perform
various tasks, all of which were
unfamiliar to them and most of
which were diriy and laborious,
took hold with a spirit of determination and showed an intelligence
in doing the work which provoked
the warm admiration of the company's officers who had charge of
them.
We wish to thank you heartily
and sincerely for permitting these
young men to come to our assistance, and hope that you will express to the students who were
accepted for the service, as well
as those who offered and could not
be accepted, our high appreciation
of their willingness to assist us.
Yours respectfully,
G. R. SINNICKSON,
Superintendent.
Dn. F. J. GIOODNOW,
President, Johns Hopkins Uiviversity, Baltimore, Md.
DEAR DR. GOODNOW :
Now that the critical transportation situation, caused by many
of our employees leaving their positions, has in a large measure
passed, I want to express, on behalf of,the officers of the Pennsylvania System, thanks and appreciation for the assistance rendered us in the emergency by the
students of your institution.
We are deeply grateful for your
co-operation in making it possible
for your undergraduates to temporarily leave their studies, and
to the boys who, from a sense of
public duty, so whole-heartedly
threw themselves into the breach
and enabled us to cope with the
(Continued on page 6, col. 3)

There has been established at
this University within the past
few weeks a company of "The
Scabbard and Blade," an honorary fraternity for the members of
the Reserve Officers' Training
Corps. Its chief mission is to
instil such a spirit into the work
of the Military Department that
the latter will be enabled to graduate, after four years of intensive
training, reserve officers of the
highest possible type.
The society is an old one, and
has its companies in a great number of the foremost military institutions throughout the country.
Johns Hopkins is one of the first
of those institutions which are
not purely military, to be added
to its roll of companies. Membership is limited to such. of the
cadet commissioned officers who
have reached a prescribed standard of proficiency, and as such is
.a great& coveted honor.
Steps were taken early this
spring toward securing the formation of a company at Johns
*Hopkins, and affairs moved in
such a manner that the installation of the charter members was
held on Thursday, April 8. This
initiation ceremony took place at
the Hotel Emerson, and was preceded by a dinner. The charter
members include Cadet Captains
Fred Bresee, Jr., L. G. Smith and
H. B. Shaw, and Lieutenants F.
H. Townsend, C. I. Krantz, F. F.
Torsch and N. N. Holland. Captain 0. 0. Ellis is the first honorary member.
At the first business meeting,
on Thursday of last week, at the
Johns Hopkins Club, the formal
organization was completed. Fred
Bresee was elected captain of the
company, F. H. Townsend its
first lieutenant, C. I. Krantz its
second lieutenant, and L. G.
Smith its first sergeant. The chief
topic of discussion was the work
which is still necessary to be done
if• this R. 0. T. C. unit is to be
placed upon the distinguished
list.
In order to further promote
discussion of the honor system
among the undergraduates of
Dartmouth College, The Bailsmonth (the college daily paper)
has arranged a monster debate on
this. subject. Two of the best debaters of the college have agreed
to take the affirmative against all
comers. '

which will be compulsory for

curriculum at Oberlin, because
the students there are said to
show a surprising lack of humor.
The Ladies' Home Journca will
be used as collateral reading

The 1920 Hullabaloo is now out
of the hands of the *Board and
rapidly being assembled by the
printer into the traditional book,
the general makeup of which is so
well known to Hopkins men. This
year's book, however, will be an
exception in some respects. It is
indeed doubtful whether many
Hopkins men will recognize the
old book as the old Hullabaloo, at
first glance. It has been the desire of the Board to embody as
many new features in the 1920
book as possible without, at the
same time, robbing it of 'distinctive Hopkins traditions. On June
1, therefore, those who have subscribed will receive for $3.00 a
book that cost nearly $10.00 to
put out; a book that at the same
time embodies both Hopkins' traditions and all the attractive innovations that Hopkins' students
could contrive.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LEITER:

Sir—Lest we forget, the Barn
is the Student Activity Building,
owned by the students, and should
be respected by them. Comfort
and carelessness are very different. It may be excusable to put
one's feet in the chairs, if that
adds comfort, but the throwing
of checkers, checker-boards, magazines, books, and even chairs, adds
comfort to none and hinders the
use of these things to all; and
is, therefore, inexcusable.
Again, we find the old-time
practice of eating lunches, carrying sodas, sundaes, bottles of
milk, etc., upstairs, and the care• less throwing about of papers.
Several months ago this was
stopped for a while through the
efforts of the Student Council,
but the effect has worn off, and
we find our community room a
veritable pig-pen. It's time that
we conduct ourselves as college
men, and think of the other felINDIGNANT.
low.
To the Editor of THE NEws-LETTER:

Junior Class Meeting.

At a recent meeting of the
Junior Class, Prof. C. C. Thomas,
of the School of Engineering, was
elected honorary president. A
banquet committee, consisting of
Bond Collins, chairman; Holmes
Boyd and E. R. Taylor, was also
elected.

According to recent statistics,
795 Princeton men are engaged
in campus activities. This includes men out for athletics, musical clubs and college publication. Nearly one-half of the
places in the sports are filled by
freshmen, while the majority of
men in other activities are in the
higher classes.

The National Football Rules'
Committee has decided that football shall be played without the
punt out after the touchdown.
The team making the touchdown
can bring the football out to any
distance and to a point directly
in front of the goal posts or elsewhere, and the try for the goal
will remain a free kick .from
placement.
•

Sir—The other day one of our
illustrious representatives to the
Student Council, when that illustrious body was discussing the
question of awards to non-athletic
activities in the University, somewhat startled the president of
the oldest activity at Hopkins by
proposing that it receive no recognition. When the young man
under discussion made the statement that the "Combined Musical
Clubs of the Johns Hopkins University" is dead, he displayed one
of two things: Either that he does
not appreciate good music, both
classical or modern, for which he
is to be pitied; or that, as he
does not support the Hopkins ac' tivities, he is not truly a representative of the student body, for
which he should be compelled to
mete out this latter just reward.
I suggest that the young man
prevent displaying such startling
ignorance again by purchasing a
ticket to .the Homewood concert,
to be given on April 30.
A. G.L.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, APRIL
INTER-CLASS MEET SUCCESS

RADIO APPARATUS INSTALLED

Spirited Competition Shown and Much
New Material Revealed—Freshmen Easily Winners.

Several Successful Experiments Have
Been Made—improvements to Be
Made in Near Future.

The freshmen were easily victorious in the inter-class track
meet, held on Homewood Field
last Monday, amassing a total of
79 points, more than twice as
many as the sophomores, who
came second with 321/
2. The juniors and seniors annexed 201/
2 and
16 points, respectively. Nevertheless, the meet was spirited and
brought forth much latent "pep"
and material in the four classes.
Aaronson, a freshman, sprang
a big surprise by romping off
with four first places, besides running on the winning relay team.
He was the highest individual
point-winner, with "Joe" Thompson, captain of the freshman
team, second, and John Marshall,
the sophomore "dark horse,"
third. Heiner, a junior, captured
the 440-yard junior, while Edwards, a freshman, won the 880yard junior. Mu'liken, running
true to form, walked away with
the 1,000-yard senior 'Varsity,
with Norwood, a senior, and
Graves, a graduate, second and
third, respectively. The half-mile
relay was the most hotly contested event of the day, and was won
by the freshmen'in 1 minute 383/s
seconds over the sophomore team.
Summary of events:

Very gratifying results have
been accomplished by a few of
the radio enthusiasts at Hopkins.
Through the efforts of Dr. E. 0.
Hulburt, a license has been procured, and the apparatus installed
in the Mechanical Engineering
Building is now being operated.
The transmitter consists of a onehalf, 500 cycle panel set, manufactured by the National Electric
Signaling Company. For receiving purposes, various - types of
vacuum tubes and amplifiers are
employed.
Several nights ago, J. C. Lewis,
B. Van Ness and W. U. Evans
succeeded in communicating with
an amateur station located at
Cambridge Springs, Pa., a distance of about 300 miles. Loud
signals have been reported by several Washington stations, and the
first of a series of tests with the
Bureau of Standards located
there has been successfully carHed out. Further tests are being arranged by Mr. Gregory
Breit, a graduate student in'radio
engineering. Another advance
will be the construction and installation of a radio-phone set.
Some inefficiency is due to the
very large antennae, which is
about twice as long as it should
be for work on the lower range
of wave lengths to which amateur
and experimental stations are restricted. However, Dr. Hulburt
has arranged to have another antennae constructed, and this
should increase the efficiency to
such an extent that it will be
reasonable to hope to communicate with stations within a radius
of a thousand miles.
The experiments have been carried on under the direction of Dr.
E. 0. Hulburt, who had much
experience in radio while in
France, and is now conducting
the radio course at Hopkins.

In a recent number of the Synthese Historique," which was dedicated to the United States, appeared a very able article entitled, "L'esprit national dans la
poesie Americaine" (The distinctive American spirit evident in
American poetry), by Dr. Chinard, of the French faculty. Dr.
Chinard says that America has
produced as many as a hundred
distinctly American poets—poets
who are not English poets writing in America, but American
poets writing in a style which
the American nation alone can
produce, and with a philosophy
distinctly American.
Dr. Chinard's preference among
American poets seems to be Whittier. He says that although
Whittier is not as polished as
either Emerson, with his philosophical studies, or Longfellow,
with his wealth of books, he is,
nevertheless—if any poet can be
said to represent the entire American nation, with its diverse divisions and consequently differences of occupation and temperament—the true American poet of
the middle of the nineteenth century.
The latest truly American poet
is Walt Whitman, who, says Dr.
Chinard, could have been produced in no other place than
America. He seems, however,
somewhat afraid of the radical
and fervent democracy of Whitman, and hastens to caution his
readers against the radicalism of
this great distinctively American
poet.
Dr. Knight Dunlap left last
Tuesday for New Orleans to attend a meeting of the Southern
Society for Psychology and Philosophy, of which he is president.
He will return some time this
week.
Dr. John Martin Vincent, professor of European history, who
has been seriously ill with the influenza, is now greatly improved.

FULTON BRAMBLE GIVES TALK
"Joseph Conrad" Was the Subject Read
Before the Literary Club Last Friday—Max Levin Gives Reading.

"Joseph Conrad" was the subject of a carefully prepared paper read before the Literary Club
by Fulton Bramble last Friday
evening at the Homewood Club.
Max Levin also presented the first
half of his discourse on "Jews
and Their Literature" at this
meting.
Bramble first gave a brief biography of Joseph Conrad, and
then proceeded to point out the
distinctive characteristics of his
novels. In this connection, he
read a number of passages from
Conrad's representative works to
illustrate the author's unique
power.

Conrad was a native of Poland,
and his mastery of English, a foreign language, is consequently all
the greater achievement. His
first novels, indeed, bear evidence
of this early struggle with a new
language, acquired only after
years of residence in Poland.
The characters of Conrad's
novels are singularly natural persons, and each novel merely gives
a series of episodes from their
lives. He rarely analyses their
characters, but prefers to leave
the reader to form his own impressions. The absence of a
strong plot is the principal weakness of Conrad's novels, and for
this reason it is probable that
they will not long enjoy great
popularity, was Bramble's conclusion.
After a short discussion of this
paper, Max Levin read the first
half of his paper on "Jews and

VICTROLA SPECIALISTS

Their Literature." The discourse
was, as he explained, really only
an introduction to the second
half of his paper. Levin traced •
the history of the Jewish people
from the time of Abraham up to
the death of Christ, and dwelt
particularly upon the, contributions of the Hebrew writers to
the Old Testament. The books of
the Prophets, Levin pointed out,
contain some of the sublimest
poetry in any literature.
At the next meeting, May 7,
Levin will read the remainder of
his paper, and W. Wiscott will
present a paper on "Andreyeff
and Russian Literature." President Goetz announced that an
effort was being made to secure
Alfred Noyes and Vachel Lindsay
to speak before the club.
